content:
I wonder why not prove things about ConditionallyCompleteLinearOrderedField instead of prove things about \R in Mathlib which is a certain instance of that. Usually real numbers are axiomatically defined, seemingly the first approach suits that better.
I didn't find much discussion/explaination about that, so I ask here.

Sometimes it's easier just to have a concrete type called R\RR, it fits better with how mathematicians talk about things. We should have all the infrastructure to translate facts about R\RR to facts about arbitrary complete Archimedean ordered fields and vice versa but I should think that many mathematicians would be confused if we were telling them that the way to say "let V be a real vector space" is "let R be any complete Archimedean ordered field and..."

Maybe a global 'variable {\R : ConditionallyCompleteLinearOrderedField}' or some hacks could be used to make sure a 'standard (but abstract) Real number' is always used, under this there's no need to concern 'which' complete Archimedean ordered field is used. Could this lead to any undesirable consequences?
Can you say why you think this would be a good idea? Do you have a particular application in mind?
Yeah right, the reason this is not done is probably because there is no reason to have another ConditionallyCompleteLinearOrderedField usually

I completely agree with Robin on 'there is no reason to have another ConditionallyCompleteLinearOrderedField usually'. I just think abstracting it is more conceptually sound. I'm concerned someone might delve into the specifics of the real number construction and establish a result that only holds for a particular model.
Also there is the advantage of Cauchy sequences that you can type #eval and see something.

Yusuke Inoue said:

I completely agree with Robin on 'there is no reason to have another ConditionallyCompleteLinearOrderedField usually'. I just think abstracting it is more conceptually sound. I'm concerned someone might delve into the specifics of the real number construction and establish a result that only holds for a particular model.

And why would this be a problem?
Even though the premise sounds very far-fetched to me, such a result wouldn't get through mathlib review anyway.
And I guess that the proof that Cauchy sequences satisfy the axioms of the reals really does use the particular model
